node.title: Boy, 7, who drowned in neighbour's pool remembered as 'lovely, affectionate and caring' child
node.description: A boy, 7, who drowned in his neighbour's pool north of Adelaide has been remembered by his grieving family as a "lovely" child.

node.title: KiwiRail group chief executive Greg Miller quits
node.description: KiwiRail group chief executive Greg Miller has resigned effective immediately due to the "recent and sustained allegations in the media" which he denies, the company says. Audio

node.title: Review into use of segregation and force in NZ prisons underway
node.description: The review will look at whether Corrections practices are consistent with the law and policies and procedures. It's one of many sparked by the treatment inmates at Auckland Women's Prison.

node.title: Summer fire risk could be elevated by lower crew levels
node.description: More than 1500 firefighters remain unvaccinated as a government deadline looms on Monday.

node.title: Red StagTimber offers cash incentive for double vaxxed workers
node.description: A Rotorua timber company is dishing out big bucks in a bid to get as many workers possible double dosed.

node.title: Protesters teargassed as they call for Solomon Islands PM to step down
node.description: Police in Solomon Islands use tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse large crowds that turned out in the capital Honiara this afternoon, demanding the country's Prime Minister step down.

node.title: Teens behind 'horrendous' killing of 14 kangaroos weep in court
node.description: The magistrate said the boys, both 17, carried out the act "without any real rationale other than a brain explosion".

node.title: Covid-19 update: 215 community cases in New Zealand today
node.description: There have been 215 new community cases of Covid-19 reported in New Zealand today, including 181 in Auckland, 18 in Waikato, three in Northland and 12 in the Bay of Plenty

node.title: The Death Knell for Hong Kong’s Democracy
node.description: Shrinking the public space that preserves the memory of the 1989 Beijing uprising has effectively turned Hong Kong into another silent mainland city.

node.title: The AFL draft is here — join the discussion as we count down to the first pick
node.description: The AFL draft is here, as some of best young players in the country launch their journeys with new clubs. Follow all the discussion and every pick in our live blog.

node.title: George Christensen likens COVID-19 restrictions to Hitler, Pol Pot regimes
node.description: Outspoken Coalition backbencher George Christensen has used a speech in federal parliament to liken state and territory COVID-19 restrictions to the despotic regimes of Nazi Germany and Cambodia, calling for civil disobedience as a response.

node.title: NSW man charged with using social media to advocate violence against politicians
node.description: The ABC understands the Prime Minister Scott Morrison and Victorian Premier Dan Andrews were among those targeted by 37-year-old farmhand Wade Homewood.

node.title: 'This is about the federal election': Palaszczuk takes aim at Commonwealth over COVID test confusion
node.description: Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk says she was unaware until yesterday that people coming to Queensland would not have to pay for a COVID-19 test to enter the state, despite the cost being covered by an inter-governmental deal since the pandemic began.

node.title: Recording paints St Basil's aged care home as 'place of neglect' during deadly COVID-19 outbreak
node.description: A woman — who lost both her parents during a COVID-19 outbreak at an aged care home in Melbourne's north that killed 50 people — gives evidence that her father wasn't provided food as the crisis engulfed the facility.

node.title: Before Richard Ludwig's company went bust, he and his advisers smuggled more than $740,000 out of the business
node.description: On the surface, it appeared to be another business going to the wall after failing to pay its mounting bills. But the reality was very different.

node.title: Former Theranos CEO Holmes Yet to Enact Defense She Was Manipulated by Former Lover
node.description: Elizabeth Holmes acknowledged she made mistakes as CEO of the disgraced blood testing tech company, but insisted she always believed the company would succeed.

node.title: Sydney removalists sentenced over COVID trip days before family tragedy
node.description: The three men were en route to the Central West when one of their COVID tests came back positive. Days later, the mother of two of the men died of the virus.

node.title: Black Caps 'realise the enormity of the challenge ahead'
node.description: The Black Caps enter the Test series against India a little wary with players having had a mixed buildup.

node.title: Vaccine hesitancy threatens Silver Ferns' programme
node.description: Vaccine hesitancy among some Silver Ferns' squad members could put a major spanner in the works as the side builds up to next year's Commonwealth Games.

node.title: Sports ponder impact of new COVID travel rules
node.description: New Zealand sports teams are still digesting the latest rules around the re-opening of the country and what it might mean for their respective competitions.

node.title: Wānaka A&P show to go ahead
node.description: One of the South Island's biggest agricultural shows will go ahead next year, bucking the trend of widespread cancellations of A&P shows around the country.

node.title: Biden to Nominate Shalanda Young as Budget Director
node.description: Ms. Young, the acting head of the Office of Management and Budget, would be the first Black woman to hold the post on a permanent basis.

node.title: Pentagon Forms a Group to Examine Unexplained Aerial Sightings
node.description: The announcement follows a report that failed to clarify strange phenomena observed by military pilots and others over the past two decades.

node.title: Native American Tribes Lobbying For Return of 6000 Remains Receive Boost in Their Case
node.description: After a discovery, tribal officials said the University of Alabama will violate federal law if the items retrieved are not given back to the tribes.

node.title: Energy Secretary Slams Big Oil's 'Enormous Profits' as Travelers Face Sticker Shock
node.description: "The oil companies have taken advantage of [the] moment," the secretary said.

node.title: New Mexico Lawmakers Search Ways to Entice Film Industry in Wake of Alec Baldwin Incident
node.description: Film productions in New Mexico spent $624 million in the state over the last year, which lawmakers used as a defense of the state's rebate incentive Tuesday.

node.title: Conservative Legislators Call for Audits in 50 States in Bid to Decertify Joe Biden's Win
node.description: The letter does not cite any specific instances of proven or alleged corruption.

node.title: Climate activist's jail time considered 'too harsh' by some, backed by others
node.description: Civil libertarian's don't support the 12 month jail sentence handed to a climate activist over anti-coal protests, but two politicians say it was the right move.

node.title: A2 Milk to fight second class action suit in Victoria
node.description: Speciality dairy company A2 Milk says it will vigourously defend itself against a second class action to be filed against it in the Supreme Court of Victoria.

node.title: Juul Vaping Settlement Sends Millions From Company to State Campaigns Against Its Product
node.description: Arizona has already received $22.5 million from Eonsmoke, an electronic cigarette company that has since shut down, in a different lawsuit.
